text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on January 23 in history.
1516 - Ferdinand II of Aragon died and was succeeded as King of Spain by his grandson Charles V.
1622 - William Baffin, British navigator and explorer who gave his name to Baffin Island, died.
1668 - Holland, Britain and Sweden signed the Alliance of the Hague, known as the Triple Alliance, under which they agreed to aid one another if attacked.
1719 - The Principality of Liechtenstein was formed by the amalgamation of Vaduz and Schellenberg.
1783 - Stendhal, French novelist, born as Marie Henri Beyle. His masterpieces, "Le Rouge et le Noir" and "La Chartreuse de Parme", did not receive widespread recognition during his life.
1793 - Russia and Prussia agreed to a second partition of Poland.
1806 - William Pitt the younger, British prime minister, died. At the age of 24, he became Britain's youngest prime minister.

1832 - Edouard Manet, French painter, born. His "Dejeuner sur l'herbe" scandalised the critics but won him the enthusiasm of a group of young painters who became the forerunners of the Impressionists.
1883 - Gustave Dore, French artist and illustrator, died. One of the most successful book illustrators of the 19th century who was famed for his dream-like scenes.
1898 - Sergei Mikhailovich Eisenstein, Russian film director, born. His films include "The Battleship Potemkin" and "Ten Days that Shook the World".
1900 - In the second British-Boer War, the British attempt to break through the Boer lines to relieve Ladysmith was thwarted at the Battle of Spion Kop.
1903 - Randolph Scott, U.S. film actor in numerous westerns, born as Randolph Crance.
1928 - Jeanne Moreau, French stage and screen actress, born. Her films include "Les Liaisons Dangereuses" and "Jules et Jim".
1931 - Anna Pavlova, Russian dancer and one of the most celebrated prima ballerinas of her time, died.
1937 - The trial of seventeen leading Communists began in Moscow, after they were accused of involvement in a plot led by Leon Trotsky to overthrow the regime and assassinate its leaders.
1943 - In World War Two, the British under Field Marshal Montgomery captured Tripoli, Libya.

1943 - After nine days of talks in Casablanca, President Roosevelt and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill agree to put an invasion of Italy ahead of opening a second front in northwestern Europe.
1944 - Edvard Munch, Norwegian painter, died. His most notable work is "The Scream".
1960 - The U.S. navy bathyscaphe Trieste dived to a record depth of 10,916 metres (35,810 feet) in the Pacific Ocean.
1961 - Venezuela's 26th constitution was promulgated by President Betancourt.

1963 - Harold "Kim" Philby, British journalist in Beirut, disappeared. Later in the year it was revealed that he was the third man in the Burgess-Maclean espionage affair and had been granted asylum in Moscow.
1968 - The North Koreans seized the American ship USS Pueblo, claiming it was spying. The crew were held until December.

1976 - Paul Robeson, U.S. singer and actor, died. Best known for the song "Ole Man River." After the Second World War he turned increasingly to politics and his left-wing views led to him being ostracised at home. He left for Europe in 1958.
1978 - Baron Edouard-Jean Empain, one of Europe's most powerful industrialists, was kidnapped in Paris. He was freed on March 26.
1983 - Soviet satellite Cosmos 1402 entered Earth's atmosphere and crashed into the Indian Ocean.
1989 - Spanish surrealist painter Salvador Dali died. He was buried in a crypt under a glass dome in the Dali museum in Figueras, in Catalonia.
1995 - Jacques Delors formally stepped down as European Commission president, handing over to Jacques Santer after 10 years of steering Europe towards closer union.
